No change since last week.    "There are confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Afghanistan. National airports are open.  The Ministry of Public Health requires a negative PCR test, conducted within 96 hours of travel, for all incoming passengers.    People arriving from other countries and who do not show symptoms of COVID-19 are advised to self-quarantine at home for 14 days.  If you have any symptoms, you are instructed to contact the Ministry of Public Health and seek care."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210202072319/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change since last week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210202072319/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Afghanistan? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Testing is available at [...] laboratories in Kabul. The price is approximately $60-100 USD and results are provided in English"
I continue to find no concrete reports around how/if contact tracing is occurring in Afghanistan.

"Bangladesh has announced that it will extend the closure of educational institutions for a further 14-day stretch, a straight 11-month shutdown of in-person education after the first COVID-19 case was registered in the country in March last year, a senior official confirmed on Sunday." - Feb 14 2021 https://web.archive.org/web/20210223064239/https://www.yenisafak.com/en/world/bangladesh-extends-closure-of-education-institutions-3560728

https://web.archive.org/web/20210224094933/https://bdnews24.com/education/2021/02/22/bangladesh-to-decide-on-reopening-schools-as-pandemic-ebbs "Bangladesh to decide on reopening schools as pandemic ebbs ... Islam said: “We are yet to decide on a date of reopening. The prime minister has asked us to confirm the inoculation of teachers and other education officials.”  “If not this week, we will definitely sit next Sunday or Monday. We will hopefully be able to reach a decision after sitting with specialists, law-enforcement officials and local administrations.”    Islam mentioned that an inter-ministerial meeting would be held to come to a decision."

"Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.  Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  Residents must work from home.  Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.  COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centers will be closed.  No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222000259/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Those arriving from, or transiting, the UK are required to quarantine at a government facility, or government approved hotel, where they will be tested for COVID-19 after seven days. Those testing negative for COVID-19 in that test will be allowed to complete the remainder of the 14 day quarantine period through ‘home quarantine’. Those testing positive will be transferred to a designated government hospital where their remaining quarantine period will be assessed and determined. The Bangladesh authorities will retain passports of passengers while they remain in quarantine and will return them at the end of the quarantine period. Passengers arriving in Bangladesh, from countries other than the UK (i.e. NOT the UK) need to quarantine for 14 days. Typically this can be completed as self-quarantine but health officials at the point of entry to Bangladesh will assess whether passengers are able to self-quarantine or need to be taken to a government facility. In all circumstances, people staying in a government approved hotel, government facility or hospital will need to cover the costs of those stays." https://archive.vn/1FzqE#selection-689.0-692.0

"Entry to Bangladesh  Bangladesh authorities have said passengers arriving from coronavirus-affected countries, including the UK, should complete Health Declaration Forms and Passenger Locator Forms provided by cabin crew. You may be subjected to additional health screening measures at the airport.  Medical certificate  On arrival in Bangladesh, all foreign nationals need to produce a medical certificate issued within 72 hours of travel indicating the passenger is COVID-19 negative. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.  Quarantine requirements  Those arriving from, or transiting, the UK are required to quarantine at a government facility, or government approved hotel, where they will be tested for COVID-19 after seven days. Those testing negative for COVID-19 in that test will be allowed to complete the remainder of the 14 day quarantine period through ‘home quarantine’. Those testing positive will be transferred to a designated government hospital where their remaining quarantine period will be assessed and determined. The Bangladesh authorities will retain passports of passengers while they remain in quarantine and will return them at the end of the quarantine period. Passengers arriving in Bangladesh, from countries other than the UK (i.e. NOT the UK) need to quarantine for 14 days. Typically this can be completed as self-quarantine but health officials at the point of entry to Bangladesh will assess whether passengers are able to self-quarantine or need to be taken to a government facility. In all circumstances, people staying in a government approved hotel, government facility or hospital will need to cover the costs of those stays."  https://archive.vn/nKDj5#selection-669.0-689.1114

"Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Bangladesh?  Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  The Government of Bangladesh has provided a list of recommended COVID-19 testing facilities for international passengers here. Those wishing to get tested will have to pay for their own COVID-19 test."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222000259/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Fines for Non-Compliance:    As of July 23, 2020, the Government of Bangladesh will take legal action against those not wearing masks or social distancing. Since May 30, the Government of Bangladesh has made wearing masks and social distancing mandatory when outside the home. Public administrators in Khulna Division have instituted a fine of TK 4,000 for those not adhering to this order."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222000259/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A; Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine doses  Pilot Vaccine Drive started on Jan 28     "Bangladesh is expected to receive 12.5 million doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine in the first half of 2021 under COVAX, the WHO-backed global scheme for distributing the coronavirus vaccines.  The two-day piloting was successfully carried out on January 28, but none of the 567 volunteers who took the first shot of the two-dose Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine has complained of any major side effect.  While the government`s target was to vaccinate 260,000 people each day, only 3,28,000 people got registered online in eleven days as of Saturday afternoon.  The doses will be administered in five stages under three phases. Priorities will be given to health workers and others on the frontline."  - https://archive.vn/ZxDLu#selection-1541.1-1488.58 "Bangladesh rolls out Covid-19 vaccine from Serum Institute of India", Feb 07, 2021    "The government is administering the Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine doses, manufactured by the Serum Institute of India, for free."   "More than 900,000 people have received their first dose of the coronavirus vaccine in Bangladesh in seven days since the mass inoculation began on Feb 7."   "Over 900,000 people take COVID vaccine in Bangladesh in seven days" - Feb 14 2021 - https://archive.vn/y1TCa#selection-1039.0-1042.0

A; Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine     19 Feb 2021: "Bangladesh gives COVID vaccine to over 1.8m people in 11 days: Only 537 of those who got the jabs so far reported mild side effects, according to the Directorate General of Health Services or DGHS.    At the 46 hospitals and centres in Dhaka, over 32,000 people took the jab on Thursday, with Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Medical University administering the highest number of 1,425.  Division-wise, Dhaka administered 73,514 doses, Mymensingh 11,901, Chattogram 54,788, Rajshahi 32,224, Rangpur 25,579, Khulna 34,195, Barishal 14,444 and Sylhet 15,300.  The government is administering the Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine doses, manufactured by the Serum Institute of India, for free.  It has targeted to give the vaccines to total 130 million people, with 3.5 million doses in the first month of the drive.  Bangladesh started the mass immunisation drive with seven million doses of the vaccine.  The Indian government sent two million doses as gift while Bangladesh imported five million doses under a deal to buy 30 million doses.  The DGHS said they have the capacity to administer 300,000 doses a day."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210223070132/https://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2021/02/19/bangladesh-gives-covid-vaccine-to-over-1.8m-people-in-11-days

A, C; Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine    "The country has focused on inoculating the elderly, frontline health workers and security forces since its vaccination drive launched early this month, but plans to eventually cover about 80 per cent of the population.  ...  The South Asian nation has so far vaccinated nearly three million people aged 40 or above with the AstraZeneca jab, but has scrapped the age restriction for sex workers at the town of Daulatdia in the country's west."    Note: unclear is sex workers would qualify as "clinically vulnerable groups".    https://archive.vn/JLeTb#selection-1583.0-1600.0

All schools will open as scheduled by the education ministry. Random testing for students and teachers will be carried out every two weeks. Health focal persons have been identified to monitor compliance and surveillance on campus.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

All offices and institutions to open. The COVID-19 Safety focal office in all offices must ensure that all COVID-19 norms are in place and implemented.  All shops, restaurants and business entities can open.  The closure time is 9pm.  For hair saloons and barber shops, extra precaution to maintain proper hygiene and safety protocols will be imposed.  Mandatory COVID-19 testing every two weeks will be carried out.  Opening of entertainment centers of movie halls, clubs, karaokes and drayangs will be announced at a later date.  All sporting activities are allowed but without any spectators.  Closure time is 11pm.  No tournaments are allowed, unless approved by the Bhutan Olympic Committee.  For traditional games of archery and khuru, only 10 participants are allowed at a time.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
Some region within Bhutan can open, but other remain closed    Bhutan Government Website: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222014916/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/5726-2/

While gathering of any sort is discouraged, for community based religious congregation, a maximum of 25 people can participate. Prior approval must be sought from the local taskforce.  Religious gatherings at home must be limited to family members.  For funeral rites to be restricted to close circles.  Pilgrimage, menchu, tsachu and hiking are allowed.  For conferences, seminars, workshops and training, a maximum of only 25 people are allowed to gather.  The COVID-19 safety focal officers must maintain proper record of the attendees.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

For conferences, seminars, workshops and training, a maximum of only 25 people are allowed to gather.  The COVID-19 safety focal officers must maintain proper record of the attendees.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.

While gathering of any sort is discouraged, for community based religious congregation, a maximum of 25 people can participate. Prior approval must be sought from the local taskforce.  Religious gatherings at home must be limited to family members.  For funeral rites to be restricted to close circles.  Pilgrimage, menchu, tsachu and hiking are allowed.  For conferences, seminars, workshops and training, a maximum of only 25 people are allowed to gather.  The COVID-19 safety focal officers must maintain proper record of the attendees.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

Inter-dzongkhag movement is allowed.  Public transports such as buses and taxis can operate.  Quarantine requirement from Thimphu and Paro is being lifted.  Seven-day mandatory quarantine will continue for those travelling from high risk to low risk areas.  All travellers must register with Check Post Management System (CPMS) prior to their travel.  Besides random testing of travellers along the check points, the public transport drivers will have to undergo mandatory testing every two weeks  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.

Besides random testing of travellers along the check points, the public transport drivers will have to undergo mandatory testing every two weeks.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

the battle is only half won as we continue to sail through the pandemic, that too amid peak winter. We could regress into a situation far more disastrous if we let our guards down today.  Therefore, concerted efforts are being made to heighten surveillance along the borders and entry points with enhanced vigilance and improved operating procedures.  More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways.  Above all, we are anticipating the roll out of the nationwide COVID-19 vaccination program that will protect our people and enable us to prevent the outbreak of the disease as we venture forward.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.

The battle is only half won as we continue to sail through the pandemic, that too amid peak winter. We could regress into a situation far more disastrous if we let our guards down today.    Therefore, concerted efforts are being made to heighten surveillance along the borders and entry points with enhanced vigilance and improved operating procedures.    More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways. The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210201002038/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No Change.    IMF Web Archived Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222014756/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
https://web.archive.org/web/20210222014756/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Many of these measures were extended under Phase II (July 8), including the waiver of interest on loans (until September 2020) and partial waiver (until March 2021), extension of deferred monthly loan instalment repayment (until June 2021)  http://web.archive.org/web/20210201002038/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways.  Besides random testing of travellers along the check points, the public transport drivers will have to undergo mandatory testing every two weeks.  All schools will open as scheduled by the education ministry. Random testing for students and teachers will be carried out every two weeks. Different states are requiring/recommending in-person attendance for students for different levels -- which also means that depending on the state, they are requiring students at certain grades/classes/levels to NOT attend.    "Haryana Schools For Classes 1-2 to Reopen From March 1 ... School Reopening News: The development comes after the state government opened the schools for classes 3-5 from February 24." - https://archive.vn/VHv5I#selection-733.0-733.124    https://archive.vn/DmOLd -   "Feb 28 2021: School reopening news: Mizoram, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar will be reopening their schools for more students and colleges from March 1.   Mizoram will be reopening its colleges, universities and other higher educational institutions from March 1.   Meghalaya has already reopened its schools for Classes 9 to 12.   Bihar will be reopening its schools for Classes 1 to 5 from March 1. Schools will be allowed to hold classes for each batch on alternate days. The government had issued guidelines to reopen their schools. Offline classes for students of Classes 9 to 12 had started on January 4 in Bihar. Following this on February 8, schools in Bihar were reopened for students of Classes 6 to 8.  Uttarakhand will be reopening its colleges and universities from tomorrow for the first time since the COVID-19 lockdown. Earlier, the schools in Uttarakhand for students of Classes 6 to 9 reopened on February 8. Schools in the state had been reopened earlier in November last year only for classes 10 and 12.  Uttar Pradesh will be reopening schools for Classes 1 to 5 from March 1."

Official guidance by the Min. of Home Affairs:   Dated Jan 27th 2021: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201182323/https://www.mha.gov.in/sites/default/files/MHAorderdt_27012021.pdf  Dated Feb 26th 2021: Order dated on Jan 27 (see above) Extended to be in effect till Mach 31 2021: https://archive.vn/Bysk5;   It mostly states that States and local governments will place appropriate restrictions on workplaces, shops, and public places.    "Normal services are available throughout the country, including grocery stores ... . Most retail shops and restaurants are open, though they may have reduced hours and limits on the number of patrons allowed inside. Public gatherings are restricted in size. Contact tracing and temperature scans are widely practiced, and most restaurants will require patrons to provide their name and a mobile number in order to enter the establishment.  Local areas may have additional restrictions.";   snapshot from 02/22/21 https://archive.vn/LGOaW; https://archive.vn/15XXv  snapshot from 01/25/21 https://web.archive.org/web/20210215092844/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Marking this as 2T because of freedom that local authorities have to place restrictions on certain areas and workplaces.

"To curb the spread of COVID-19, scheduled international commercial passenger air services are currently suspended however certain eligible foreign nationals are able to travel to India via Vande Bharat flights or third country flights. Availability of options for international transportation remain limited.    All land borders with Bangladesh, Bhutan, Myanmar and Nepal in East and North East India are closed for movement of people, except returning Indian nationals."  https://archive.vn/1iu4Y
"All individuals who wish to get themselves tested."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201223111002/https://www.icmr.gov.in/pdf/covid/strategy/Testing_Strategy_v6_04092020.pdf

Policy document titled "Advisory on Strategy for COVID-19 Testing in India" dated: 4th Sept 2020 lays out clear guidelines on how and where to carry out testing and "routine surveillance":  https://web.archive.org/web/20201223111002/https://www.icmr.gov.in/pdf/covid/strategy/Testing_Strategy_v6_04092020.pdf

Individuals in public spaces without a mask maybe fined per instance of non-compliance. The amount differs by region (currently Rs 2000 per instance in New Delhi).  Individuals who break quarantine maybe fined and/or detained. The severity of the punishment for non-compliance will depend upon the state government policies and level of danger the lack of quarantine posed to the public.    - https://archive.vn/15XXv#selection-2895.0-2906.0

Groups: A,B,C  Vaccine: AstraZeneca and Bharat Biotech    Guidance note for COWIN 2.0 issued by Min. of Health  "As on 24th February 2021, more than 1.23 crore (~1.09 crore 1st dose and ~14 lakh 2nd dose) doses have already administered through more than 263,000 session at more than 45,000 sites targeting the health care workers and frontline workers. In accordance with the prioritization as guided by the NEGVAC, the next phase of vaccination is due for citizens of age appropriate categories, including initially the people above 60 years of age and those aged from 45 years to 60 years and have the comorbidities. To augment and simplify the process of registration vaccination, the MoHFW is coming with COWIN 2.0, based on the feedbacks received during the implementation of Phase 1 of Covid-19 vaccination drive."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210228110952/https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/GuidancedocCOWIN2.pdf  - https://archive.vn/TNRgi    "This phase of vaccination is for citizens above 60 years of age and those aged from 45 years to 60 years and have the following comorbidities. However, any healthcare or front-line worker left out in phase one is also eligible. To augment and simplify the process of registration and vaccination, the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare introduced COWIN 2.0."  - "COVID-19 vaccination in India", Wikipedia, https://archive.vn/cJ0Jv

It was announced by the Commander of the Army and the Head of the National Operation Center for Prevention of COVID-19 Outbreak (NOCPCO) that 10 additional areas have been realised from the isolation status from 5:00 am 8th February onwards. Other targeted areas however continue to see workplace closures, cancellation of public events, restrictions on gatherings and public transportation, and stay at home requirements.     Districts no longer under isolation:   Gothameepura Housing Scheme  Gothameepura 24 Watta  Gothameepura 78 Watta  Weluwana Road (Dematagoda)  Kumarimulla Grama Niladari Division  Jumma Masjid Road  Hidra Mawatha  Aluthpara  Akaragoda  Bolana South    Source:   http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2021/02/07/news/10-areas-released-isolation  (archiving unavailable)

"The economy is predominantly open, with services such as grocery stores and other businesses operational. Areas identified by authorities as COVID-19 “hotspots” could be locked down without advance notice."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Some streets, neighborhoods, and commercial zones are currently under lockdown in Pakistan’s major cities.  Areas identified by authorities as COVID-19 “hotspots” could be locked down without advance notice. ... Pakistan issued new restrictions for weddings and large gatherings November 27.  Events must be held outdoors, are limited to 300 people, and cannot last for more than two hours."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In general: "Pakistan issued new restrictions for weddings and large gatherings November 27.  Events must be held outdoors, are limited to 300 people, and cannot last for more than two hours."    However, local authorities continue to enforce targeted, smart lockdowns as necessary without notice, which imply strict restrictions on gatherings.   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Is public transportation operating?  Yes.  According to the Government of Pakistan, individuals using public transportation – trains or buses – should wear facemasks and keep a distance of at least six feet from other individuals. Additional information is available here.  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

- https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  "The economy is predominantly open, with services such as grocery stores and other businesses operational.  Some streets, neighborhoods, and commercial zones are currently under lockdown in Pakistan’s major cities.  Areas identified by authorities as COVID-19 “hotspots” could be locked down without advance notice"
"Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  "Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes]  Upon arrival, all travelers will line up six feet (two meters) apart and undergo thermo-screening by thermo-guns and/or thermo-scanners.    [travelers from certain countries are required to] Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel."

"Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Pakistan? Yes.  Both viral antigen and RT-PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight.  Test results are regularly available in English."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change from prior notes. NCOC continue to engage in coordinating contact tracing functions carried out by local provinces in Pakistan.    In Pakistan, provinces carry out contact tracing, but the process is assisted and centrally collated, and the NCOC (National Command Operation Center) is aware of the tests done for potentially infected persons and as part of contact tracing. (source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092232/https://thediplomat.com/2020/07/inside-pakistans-covid-19-contact-tracing/)

- https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  "The Pakistan National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) announced October 28, 2020, that, effective immediately, to prevent the spread of COVID-19, masks must be worn when in public, countrywide. Islamabad Capital Territory (ICT) ordered masks must be worn in public places, including bazaars, shopping malls, and restaurants or while using public transport.  ICT’s announcement warns those not following the order may be subject to legal action."

https://web.archive.org/web/20210209082015/https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/783982-first-coronavirus-jab-administered-in-pakistan    Vaccine: Sinovax; Group: Health Care workers    "First coronavirus jab administered in Pakistan: Prime Minister Imran Khan supervising the first coronavirus shot as Pakistan kicks off its vaccination drive, on February 2, 2021  The first coronavirus vaccine was administered in Pakistan on Tuesday, given to a healthcare worker in Islamabad.    "I congratulate [all those present here] for working at great speed to import a vaccine. We also thank China for gifting us 500,000 vaccines," he said.    The premier also sought to assure the nation that the vaccine distribution across the various provinces is being done in a "just" manner. "No one should think we distributed more vaccines in a given province than in others."    He stressed the importance of healthcare workers getting the shot as "all over the world it is the healthcare workers that are most at risk".  Provinces to begin vaccination drive tomorrow."
